column2: And now the question was between the moon and the cottage.
column3: And now the question was between the moon and the cottage.

column2: The princess thought she knew the worst of the moon, and she knew nothing at all about the cottage, therefore she would stay with the moon.
column3: The princess thought she knew the worst of the moon, and she knew nothing at all about the cottage, therefore she would stay with the moon.

column2: Strange, was it not, that she should have been so long with the wise woman, and yet know NOTHING about that cottage?
column3: Strange, was it not, that she should have been so long with the wise woman, and yet know NOTHING about that cottage?

column2: First of all, the soft wind blowing gently through the dry stalks of the heather and its thousands of little bells raised a sweet rustling, which the princess took for the hissing of serpents, for you know she had been naughty for so long that she could not in a great many things tell the good from the bad.
column3: First of all, the soft wind blowing gently through the dry stalks of the heather and its thousands of little bells raised a sweet rustling, which the princess took for the hissing of serpents, for you know she had been naughty for so long that she could not in a great many things tell the good from the bad.

column2: Then nobody could deny that there, all round about the heath, like a ring of darkness, lay the gloomy fir-wood, and the princess knew what it was full of, and every now and then she thought she heard the howling of its wolves and hyenas.
column3: Then nobody could deny that there, all round about the heath, like a ring of darkness, lay the gloomy fir wood, and the princess knew what it was full of, and every now and then she thought she heard the howling of its wolves and hyenas.

column2: And who could tell but some of them might break from their covert and sweep like a shadow across the heath?
column3: And who could tell but some of them might break from their covert and sweep like a shadow across the heath?

column2: Indeed, it was not once nor twice that for a moment she was fully persuaded she saw a great beast coming leaping and bounding through the moonlight to have her all to himself.
column3: Indeed, it was not once nor twice that for a moment she was fully persuaded she saw a great beast coming leaping and bounding through the moonlight to have her all to himself.

column2: She did not know that not a single evil creature dared set foot on that heath, or that, if one should do so, it would that instant wither up and cease.
column3: She did not know that not a single evil creature dared set foot on that heath, or that, if one should do so, it would that instant wither up and cease.

column2: The wise woman, too, she felt sure, although her cottage looked asleep, was watching her at some little window.
column3: The wise woman, too, she felt sure, although her cottage looked asleep, was watching her at some little window.

column2: In this, however, she would have been quite right, if she had only imagined enough--namely, that the wise woman was watching OVER her from the little window.
column3: In this, however, she would have been quite right, if she had only imagined enough-namely, that the wise woman was watching OVER her from the little window.

column2: Hardly had the possibility arisen in her mind, before she was on her feet: if the woman was any thing short of an ogress, her cottage must be better than that horrible loneliness, with nothing in all the world but a stare; and even an ogress had at least the shape and look of a human being.
column3: Hardly had the possibility arisen in her mind, before she was on her feet: if the woman was any thing short of an ogress, her cottage must be better than that horrible loneliness, with nothing in all the world but a stare; and even an ogress had at least the shape and look of a human being.

column2: But, to her surprise, she came only to another back, for no door was to be seen. She tried the farther end, but still no door.
column3: But, to her surprise, she came only to another back, for no door was to be seen. She tried the farther end, but still no door.

column2: She must have passed it as she ran--but no--neither in gable nor in side was any to be found.
column3: She must have passed it as she ran-but no-neither in gable nor in side was any to be found.

column2: A cottage without a door!--she rushed at it in a rage and kicked at the wall with her feet.
column3: A cottage without a door!--she rushed at it in a rage and kicked at the wall with her feet.

column2: Suddenly, however, she remembered how her screaming had brought the horde of wolves and hyenas about her in the forest, and, ceasing at once, lay still, gazing yet again at the moon.
column3: Suddenly, however, she remembered how her screaming had brought the horde of wolves and hyenas about her in the forest, and, ceasing at once, lay still, gazing yet again at the moon.

column2: But the old woman--as the princess called her, not knowing that her real name was the Wise Woman--had told her that she must knock at the door: how was she to do that when there was no door?
column3: But the old woman-as the princess called her, not knowing that her real name was the Wise Woman-had told her that she must knock at the door: how was she to do that when there was no door?

column2: But again she bethought herself--that, if she could not do all she was told, she could, at least, do a part of it: if she could not knock at the door, she could at least knock--say on the wall, for there was nothing else to knock upon--and perhaps the old woman would hear her, and lift her in by some window.
column3: But again she bethought herself-that, if she could not do all she was told, she could, at least, do a part of it: if she could not knock at the door, she could at least knock-say on the wall, for there was nothing else to knock upon-and perhaps the old woman would hear her, and lift her in by some window.

column2: Thereupon, she rose at once to her feet, and picking up a stone, began to knock on the wall with it.
column3: Thereupon, she rose at once to her feet, and picking up a stone, began to knock on the wall with it.

column2: For a moment she feared the old woman would be offended, but the next, there came a voice, saying,
column3: For a moment she feared the old woman would be offended, but the next, there came a voice, saying,

column2: Who is there?
column3: Who is there?

column2: The princess answered,
column3: The princess answered,

column2: Please, old woman, I did not mean to knock so loud.
column3: Please, old woman, I did not mean to knock so loud.

column2: To this there came no reply.
column3: To this there came no reply.

column2: Then the princess knocked again, this time with her knuckles, and the voice came again, saying,
column3: Then the princess knocked again, this time with her knuckles, and the voice came again, saying,

column2: Who is there?
column3: Who is there?

column2: And the princess answered,
column3: And the princess answered,

column2: Rosamond.
column3: Rosamond.

column2: But the princess soon ventured to knock a third time.
column3: But the princess soon ventured to knock a third time.

column2: What do you want? said the voice.
column3: What do you want? said the voice.

column2: Oh, please, let me in! said the princess.
column3: Oh, please, let me in! said the princess.

column2: Then the door opened, and the princess entered.
column3: Then the door opened, and the princess entered.

column2: She looked all around, but saw nothing of the wise woman.
column3: She looked all around, but saw nothing of the wise woman.

column2: It was a single bare little room, with a white deal table, and a few old wooden chairs, a fire of fir-wood on the hearth, the smoke of which smelt sweet, and a patch of thick-growing heath in one corner.
column3: It was a single bare little room, with a white deal table, and a few old wooden chairs, a fire of fir wood on the hearth, the smoke of which smelt sweet, and a patch of thick growing heath in one corner.

column2: And what with the sufferings and terrors she had left outside, the new kind of tears she had shed, the love she had begun to feel for her parents, and the trust she had begun to place in the wise woman, it seemed to her as if her soul had grown larger of a sudden, and she had left the days of her childishness and naughtiness far behind her.
column3: And what with the sufferings and terrors she had left outside, the new kind of tears she had shed, the love she had begun to feel for her parents, and the trust she had begun to place in the wise woman, it seemed to her as if her soul had grown larger of a sudden, and she had left the days of her childishness and naughtiness far behind her.

column2: People are so ready to think themselves changed when it is only their mood that is changed!
column3: People are so ready to think themselves changed when it is only their mood that is changed!

column2: Those who are good-tempered because it is a fine day, will be ill-tempered when it rains: their selves are just the same both days; only in the one case, the fine weather has got into them, in the other the rainy.
column3: Those who are good tempered because it is a fine day, will be ill tempered when it rains: their selves are just the same both days; only in the one case, the fine weather has got into them, in the other the rainy.

column2: Then in her terror the princess grew angry, and saying to herself, "She must be somewhere in the place, else who was there to open the door to me?" began to shout and yell, and call the wise woman all the bad names she had been in the habit of throwing at her nurses.
column3: Then in her terror the princess grew angry, and saying to herself, "She must be somewhere in the place, else who was there to open the door to me?" began to shout and yell, and call the wise woman all the bad names she had been in the habit of throwing at her nurses.

column2: On the contrary, she thought she had a perfect right to be angry, for was she not most desperately ill used--and a princess too?
column3: On the contrary, she thought she had a perfect right to be angry, for was she not most desperately ill used-and a princess too?

column2: But the wind howled on, and the rain kept pouring down the chimney, and every now and then the lightning burst out, and the thunder rushed after it, as if the great lumbering sound could ever think to catch up with the swift light!
column3: But the wind howled on, and the rain kept pouring down the chimney, and every now and then the lightning burst out, and the thunder rushed after it, as if the great lumbering sound could ever think to catch up with the swift light!

column2: But being in a bad temper always makes people stupid, and presently she struck her forehead such a blow against something--she thought herself it felt like the old woman's cloak--that she fell back--not on the floor, though, but on the patch of heather, which felt as soft and pleasant as any bed in the palace.
column3: But being in a bad temper always makes people stupid, and presently she struck her forehead such a blow against something-she thought herself it felt like the old woman's cloak-that she fell back-not on the floor, though, but on the patch of heather, which felt as soft and pleasant as any bed in the palace.

column2: It was no use stopping to look about her, for what had she to do but forever look about her as she went on and on and on--never seeing any thing, and never expecting to see any thing!
column3: It was no use stopping to look about her, for what had she to do but forever look about her as she went on and on and on-never seeing any thing, and never expecting to see any thing!

column2: The only shadow of a hope she had was, that she might by slow degrees grow thinner and thinner, until at last she wore away to nothing at all; only alas! she could not detect the least sign that she had yet begun to grow thinner.
column3: The only shadow of a hope she had was, that she might by slow degrees grow thinner and thinner, until at last she wore away to nothing at all; only alas! she could not detect the least sign that she had yet begun to grow thinner.

column2: The hopelessness grew at length so unendurable that she woke with a start.
column3: The hopelessness grew at length so unendurable that she woke with a start.

column2: Seeing the face of the wise woman bending over her, she threw her arms around her neck and held up her mouth to be kissed.
column3: Seeing the face of the wise woman bending over her, she threw her arms around her neck and held up her mouth to be kissed.

column2: And the kiss of the wise woman was like the rose-gardens of Damascus.
column3: And the kiss of the wise woman was like the rose gardens of Damascus.
